title: Question: Chaining transformations onto a url
body:
I have a client that uploads an image to Cloudinary and then uses the response to crop and position the image with a transformation. The resulting image url is then sent to the backend.

In the backend, when the user profile is requested, I want to create two versions of these images:
1) the uploaded image with a max size limit (eg. `w_1024,c_fit`)
2) a thumbnail image (eg. `w_200,g_center,c_thumb`)

Because I store the public_id and transformations in the url itself it becomes tricky to chain transforms onto an existing url, and as far as I can tell I'll have to parse and manipulate the url myself if I want to achieve this. Is there anything in the libs I've missed that would allow me to do something like this:
```cloudinary.chainTransformations(secure_url, ['w_200,g_center,c_thumb'])```

Edit: I could send the client specified transforms to the api and then use that to pre-generate the 2 urls I want, however where I would like to take this is to allow the client to specify the size it needs in a graphql query.

title: Object.entries is not a function on node <= 6
body:
Version `1.12.0` uses `Object.entries` in `lib-es5` although it isn't an es5 feature. This generates the following error, using node 6 in my case:
```
/node_modules/cloudinary/lib-es5/config.js:64
      Object.entries(parsedConfig).forEach(function (_ref) {
             ^
TypeError: Object.entries is not a function
```
An easy fix is to use the [transform-es2017-object-entries](https://github.com/christensson/babel-plugin-transform-es2017-object-entries) plugin in the babel config. The reason your tests do pass is because you're using `babel-polyfill` in the test command. For the tests to be representative, they should work with the same babel config as is used to compile `lib-es5`.

title: Update Node version conditional to handle multiple-digit major versions.
body: Fixes https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/issues/217

title: Version 1.12.0 doesn't use ES6 as intended on Node versions greater than 9.
body:
In [cloudinary.js](https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/blob/5b57b63be229c3137ce96d2d8f92622cb1016dd4/cloudinary.js#L1):

`module.exports = Number(process.versions.node[0]) < 8 ? require('./lib-es5/cloudinary') : require('./lib/cloudinary');`

The first character of the Node version string in Node 10 and above is 1, which is less than 8. So the ES5 library gets required instead.

It doesn't seem like this will begin requiring the ES6 library again until Node 80 is released, which is probably not the intended behaviour.

title: fix unit test failure in archivespec.coffee
body:
Unit test was failing due to the code that parses the output from `unzip -l` ending up with three items in the array instead of two.
Modified test to use `unzip -ql` to suppress extra output, then changed the indexes to examine for the filenames

Before, array contained:

~~~

[ '---------  ---------- -----   ----',
  '   111270  09-26-2018 12:06   cloudinary_npm_test_894597_archive_1.jpg',
  '   111270  09-26-2018 12:06   cloudinary_npm_test_894597_archive_2.jpg']

~~~

After:

~~~

[ '   111270  09-26-2018 12:14   cloudinary_npm_test_285402_archive_1.jpg',
  '   111270  09-26-2018 12:14   cloudinary_npm_test_285402_archive_2.jpg' ]

~~~

Full test suite passes locally against test cloud

title: Add support for gs:// urls in uploader
body:
URL handling in upload() has special cases for non-local URLs but doesn't support gs: URL prefix
Without this, attempts to use gs: URLs are handled locally, and the file can't be loaded.

Tests pass except `should support requesting ocr analysis` which appears unrelated, and was based on running tests against a cloud which hasn't got access to OCR

Verified `gs://` upload works with an example in my own account, fetched from my own storage bucket on Google Cloud (cloud `stephencloudinary`, public ID `c3uirc0l0gq0eylnhiv0`)

In my server side, i have this config
```coffee
import URL        from 'url'
import Cloudinary from 'cloudinary'

cloudinary_url = URL.parse process.env.CLOUDINARY_URL

Cloudinary.config
  cloud_name : cloudinary_url.host
  api_key    : cloudinary_url.auth.split(':')[0]
  api_secret : cloudinary_url.auth.split(':')[1]
```

on my client side, i have this config

```coffee
import Cloudinary from 'cloudinary'
ENV = require './env'

Cloudinary.config
  cloud_name : ENV.cloudinary.cloud_name
```

```coffee
Cloudinary.uploader.upload avatar, ( error ,response ) ->

    if error

```

I'm trying to use cloudinary node SDK to upload photos from my application to the cloudinary service using below code snippet:
```
const photo = await jimp.read(file.buffer);
await photo.resize(1000, 800);
await photo.write('./tmp/photos/${filename}');
const cloudinaryPhoto = await cloudinary.uploader.upload('./tmp/photos/${filename}');
```
Now this works fine for me when uploading jpegs. The problem arises when I try to upload PNG files. For some reason Cloudinary is unable to find the specified file:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14975555/29457871-a7f41ee8-841c-11e7-9a64-3b980c608d36.png)

Although the file is in the specified directory:

Since it is working with jpegs I'm not really sure what is going wrong here. Did someone else experience the same issue? Am I forgetting some options I should pass in? 

Thanks in advance!

[feature request] Set/Override filename for streams
body:
Hey Hey,
I'm uploading to cloudinary using `cloudinary.uploader.upload_stream`, and right now when uploading with a stream, [the filename is automatically set to 'file'](https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/blob/c6aa42b11f2b0b97d904f93d2c5794da8c0cdb1b/src/uploader.coffee#L279). 

Since I do know what the filename should be, I was wondering if it would be possible to make an option for this. I tried setting the public id manually, but this obviously requires there to be no conflicting filenames and I can't guarantee this in my app. 

For now, I'd propose a `filename` option that can be passed, but maybe adding an additional parameter to `upload_stream` might also work. What would be the best implementation in your opinion?

title: util.url doesn't work for Beyoncé etc. (utf encoding)
body:
The URL function is giving us issues with image file names where there are UTF characters like cedilla and grave accents.

**Problem:** 
The current function results in `Beyonc%327e%301_kofryc`, where the `c` in `Beyonc` is untouched. This URIDecodes to `Beyonc27e01_kofryc`, which isn't the correct public_id.

The desired end url should contain a public_id something like`Beyonc%CC%A7e%CC%81_kofryc` which you can URIDecode back into the original public_id.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Try with a `public_id` like Beyonçé, and stop the debugger as it's looping over the characters in the string: https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/blob/master/src/utils.coffee#L598

It seems that because the regex doesn't match the `c` of the `ç` we're trying to represent, by the time you process the cedilla, the chance for encoding the `c` and the cedilla together into `%CC%A7` has passed:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5633265/25590679/85bd75c4-2e7f-11e7-8515-a31db6a32729.png)

Normalizing the string before sending it to the function doesn't appear to fix the issue.

Helpful links about unicode normalization:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/String/normalize
http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr15/tr15-29.html

title: undefined image url u
body:
`picture.url=response.secure_url` 
This picture.url is undefined. Means there is nothing being stored in this 

I'm using `cloudinary.uploader.upload(fileName, function(response)`

title: Poor documentation on generating upload signature for client upload
Support = and | characters within context values using escaping + test
body: Support using "=" and "|" characters within context (resource metadata) values by escaping using backslashes

title: Test/upgrade mocha
body:
Due to breaking changes on Mocha 3.X:
https://github.com/mochajs/mocha/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#300--2016-07-31
Should avoid returning promises in case when done() callback is invoked

title: Added new parameters to generate-archive api + tests
body: - Added allow_missing & skip_transformation_name to Archive API + tests

title: fix escaping of special characters in certain scenarios + tests
body:
- Selectively revert changes for escaping of public IDs and text overlays
- Additional tests were added to assure stability

title: callback error
Incorrect escaping of URLs
body: Hi! I'm having a problem with URLs not getting escaped correctly. I might have missed something, but it seems like it could be related to a recent change you made to the way you escape URLs: https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/commit/f149ba165824d9e7fd56db3650c09c923d83d4ba#diff-e7632c024955e4a1dc429d3253cbe6bcR584 The `smart_escape` function used to escape URLs this way: ``` smart_escape = (string)-> encodeURIComponent(string).replace(/%3A/g, ":").replace(/%2F/g, "/") ``` Now, it escapes URLs this way: ``` smart_escape = (string, unsafe = /([^a-zA-Z0-9_.\-\/:]+)/g)-> string.replace unsafe, (match)-> match.split("").map((c)-> "%"+c.charCodeAt(0).toString(16).toUpperCase()).join("") ``` I have a case where the `public_id` is `Snø_dfom5q`. The new escape function produces `Sn%F8_dfom5q`, while the old, and in this case correct function, produces `Sn%C3%B8_dfom5q`. The complete URLs: http://res.cloudinary.com/hanen/image/upload/Sn%F8_dfom5q.png http://res.cloudinary.com/hanen/image/upload/Sn%C3%B8_dfom5q.png If I try to open the new URL (the first one in the list above) I get the following error: ``` InvalidURI Couldn't parse the specified URI. /cloudinary_data/res/hanen/image/upload/c_limit,h_200,w_200/Sn%F8_dfom5q.png 92E2AA6CF6053C21 T9+GP9naEm0RSFY1aYSn8qGNvmlll7BE97odtnHL2c5du40aR4RQPrTsyvbNOPxh2+fDRLCPxG0= ``` I'm not an expert on URL escaping, so it's hard for me know your thinking behind your recent change and create a PR. But let me know if I can help in any way.

title: Wrong negative angle in url
body:
(using node 7.7)

This call
`cloudinary.image("sample.jpg", { angle: -20, overlay: "text:DarkText:encodedCopy" })`

should return a correct url like this
`.../image/upload/a_-20,l_text:DarkText:helloworld/v1489489711/sample.jpg`
notice: **a_-20**

however, it returns a malformed url
`/image/upload/a_min20,l_text:DarkText:helloworld/sample.jpg`
notice: **a_min20**

the minus in the rotation has be encoded incorrectly and the API call fails

title: api_call should reject promise on request error
body:
api_call does include sophisticated error handling for res error emitter, but errors emitted by request are just passed to the callback without rejecting the deferred promise. See the request [error handler](https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/blob/master/src/api.coffee#L69).

A few lines up you can see the response error handler correctly rejecting the deferred promise before callback.

title: samples out of date ?
body:
This [sample](https://github.com/cloudinary/cloudinary_npm/blob/c290aa1ba4b4c56b8c16094356c9630a4ea273d2/samples/basic/basic.js#L32) uses the pattern `upload_stream(params, callback)` but in your readme it's `upload_stream(callback, params)`.

In addition, the callback does not appear to be passed an error param.

title: Raw file upload with same public_id doesn't replace original file
body:
Hi there,

I am able to upload replacement images (using same `public_id`) successfully, but this doesn't work for raw file types like `.txt`. When I use the same `public_id` generated in the original file upload, it doesn't locate and replace this file but generates a second file with a new hash.

These are the upload options I'm using for raw files:
```
const fileDoc = FilesCollection.findOne({name: file.name});

const options = {
  tags: ["tag1", "tag2],
  invalidate: true,
  resource_type: "auto",
  use_filename: true,
  public_id: fileDoc.public_id
};
```

Also, `options.use_filename` isn't working if you're using it in conjunction with `options.folder` - it still generates a hash after the prepended folder path.

title: Special characters are not useable in the public_id
With Upload Mapping in place, api calls trigger an unhandled rejection if file is missing.
Library should reject with Error objects
body:
Rejects, callbacks, exceptions are coming back with plain object that looks like: {error: {http_code:404, message: "some message"}}.
It should be an instance of Error class.

title: Uploading using buffer or buffer.toString()
body:
first try:

```js
cloudinary.uploader.upload(req.files.avatar.data, function(result) { 
  console.log(result);
});
```
results in error message:
```
TypeError: file.match is not a function
at C:\<redacted>\node_modules\cloudinary\lib\uploader.js:67:34
```

second approach, converting the buffer to a string:
```js
cloudinary.uploader.upload(req.files.avatar.data.toString('utf8'), function(result) { 
  console.log(result);
});
```
results in error:
```
Error: Path must be a string without null bytes
       at nullCheck (fs.js:135:14)
       at Object.fs.open (fs.js:626:8)
       at ReadStream.open (fs.js:1936:6)
       at new ReadStream (fs.js:1923:10)
       at Object.fs.createReadStream (fs.js:1870:10)
       at post (C:\<redacted>\node_modules\cloudinary\lib\uploader.js:592:10)
```
IIRC, it looks like in the first instance its just not equipped to read a buffer (which it doesn't specify in docs). In second, it appears that it interpreted the stringified buffer as a file name and was a attempting to open the file and read it. This is the case I care about as the documentation on your website states that it is possible to upload file data directly. I would really prefer this approach as to storing the file to disk which creates alot of unnecessary io. So can you rectify this situation for me? What is the solution, as the documentation is certainly lacking, it doesn't even list the api for the library anywhere. the only documentation on your website is for ruby.

title: Uploading video
body:
I am working on uploading video. Here is my codes.

First try:
```
cloudinary.uploader.upload_large(videoFile,
            function(result) {console.log(result); },
            { resource_type: "video" });
```
Second try:
```
cloudinary.uploader.upload_large(videoFile,
            function(result) {console.log(result); },
            { resource_type: "auto" });
```
Thir try:
```
cloudinary.uploader.upload_large(videoFile,
            function(result) {console.log(result); },
            { resource_type: "raw" });
```

All of the code, I am getting TypeError: callback is not a function error. Is there any problem in v1_result_adapter function.

Here is the full stack trace.

```
/home/karayel/Desktop/welmio-mvc/node_modules/cloudinary/lib/utils.js:1028
          return callback(void 0, result);
                 ^

TypeError: callback is not a function
    at v1_result_adapter (/home/karayel/Desktop/welmio-mvc/node_modules/cloudinary/lib/utils.js:1028:18)
    at exports.upload_chunked_stream.chunker.on.finished_part (/home/karayel/Desktop/welmio-mvc/node_modules/cloudinary/lib/uploader.js:172:13)
    at IncomingMessage.<anonymous> (/home/karayel/Desktop/welmio-mvc/node_modules/cloudinary/lib/uploader.js:495:51)
    at emitNone (events.js:72:20)
    at IncomingMessage.emit (events.js:166:7)
    at endReadableNT (_stream_readable.js:923:12)
    at nextTickCallbackWith2Args (node.js:458:9)
    at process._tickCallback (node.js:372:17)
```

title: Missing documentation for delete?
body: How exactly do you delete images? can i delete by secure_url? Its the only thing i'm storing in db.. If not, no worries, easy to obtain the id from the secure url i assume.
